feedback.Physical object: Excluded — A Twitter handle is not a tangible entity.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Excluded — It is a digital construct but not a synthetic object in material terms.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — It has no biological basis.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — Handles can be changed by the user or system.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — It does not constitute part of a physical or architectural structure.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — The handle's representation (text) is perceivable, but the handle itself as an entity is abstract.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — It does not exist in material form.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — It functions as a pointer and can generate activity through tagging, mentions, etc.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Twitter handles are created intentionally to represent users or entities online.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Included — Handles are used to direct mentions, trigger notifications, and represent accounts.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — It does not perform computation or signal processing.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — It is not dynamic on its own.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — It is a reference to an account, not an interface.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Included — Twitter handles are integral to the platform's identity and tagging system.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — It requires a platform and user context to operate.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — The platform can technically exist without any one specific handle.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — It symbolically represents a user or entity.
feedback.Communicative: Included — It functions as a communicative handle through mentions and tags.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Excluded — Its use is governed by conventions, but it is not a logic structure.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Excluded — It does not contain internal hierarchy.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Excluded — It does not direct behavior intrinsically.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — It does not encode or reflect upon itself.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — It does not inherently represent time.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — It is an abstract pointer whose meaning depends entirely on social and platform context.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — The concept and structure of handles are culturally constructed.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Twitter defines the naming conventions and usage.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Included — It serves as an online identifier.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Included — Usage is governed by Twitter’s rules and policies.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — People are taught how to use and refer to handles.
feedback.Visible: Included — Handles are prominently displayed and searchable.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Their meaning depends on who uses them, in what setting.
feedback.Widely known: Included — The convention of handles is well known in digital communication.

encoding_notes: The Twitter handle is modeled here as a symbolic, communicative, socially-defined pointer within a digital system. It lacks physical and autonomous properties but is deeply embedded in platform logic and online identity structures. The corrected code '00C4C1FF' faithfully reflects the selected traits.
